reviewText: Amusing 40's musical-comedy with Dorothy Lamour and William Holden.  Great support from Eddie Bracken and Betty Hutton.  Saw it back on 1970's TV.  Would love to see it released re-mastered on DVD or DVD-R.  Soon, please.
I saw this movie 70 years ago. I still love to watch it this is the second movie I've bought  since then.  bring back more musicals we old guys remember them
It looks like someone recorded it off tv, made a disc and is selling it on Amazon.  It's not quality produced.  Looks like a buddy just burned a dvd for me... disappointed

While there were a few spots in this movie "The Fleet's In" that I found kind of boring (mostly some of the musical numbers) overall I did enjoy it.  William Holden was adorable in his part and while it didn't tax his abilities he was fine as always and early Dorothy Lamour was fun to watch.  Eddie Brackin and Betty Hutton provided good comic relief.  It's great to be able to find these early classic films available at Amazon.

The Fleet's In is a movie I saw on TV about 15 years ago.  There were parts of it that were very funny and I have been hoping to find it on DVD.  No luck for years, but then I found it on Amazon.  It is like a DVD that I would burn at home.  I don't know the source material that was used to record it.  Pretty fuzzy, but better than nothing.  It is the movie I was looking for but wish the quality had been better.
I wanted this movie for the music; a pair of classics: Tangerine and I Remember you. The plot is light weight, but the music is great.

my sister and i loved the movie--especially william holden's portrayal of a handsome but shy sailor.  betty hutton was darling, dorothy lamour was great, too.  they don't make them like that anymore.  sweet innocence.

Up (Single Disc Widescreen) I have been trying to find a copy of this movie for several years, so I was delighted when one was finaly available I saw the movie when frist came out, and I always liked Johnny Mercier lyrics , and of course the Jimmy Dorsey Band with Bob Eberly and Helen O'Connel.
